title: Kindred has been out for a couple of hours
body: And 20% of the community claims to be a Kindred main. This is why you disable new champs in ranked for the first 2 weeks.

I agree completely with you actually. Smite has an incredibly strict rule on new champs as often you can't play them in ranked for around 2 weeks. It works fine and everyone that plays that game seriously agrees that's how it should be.

Just a week long period would be plenty IMO. Even if balance wasn't perfected the surprise bugs and surprise op builds would be found. Plus everyone would have plenty of practice in an environment with no lasting drawbacks for others.

> [{quoted}](name=iTaLenTZ,realm=EUW,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=VKiHcnaK,comment-id=,timestamp=2015-10-14T15:35:44.787+0000)
>
> And 20% of the community claims to be a Kindred main. This is why you disable new champs in ranked for the first 2 weeks.

I disagree. This is how people learn how to play against Kindred in general. It has good sides. If people weren't claiming to be Kindred players or "mains" then how can other people even know what Kindred does? Or learn their strengths?
It's a part of learning that new champion.

Its called playing against bots. There is a reason why we have Co-op vs AI matches. That is what I use when trying out new champs. Mainly because im not a dick screwing over my team by picking a champ i have no idea how to play and then completely bombing on it and giving the team a loss that could have been avoided in PVP.

I had this yesterday when playing with a random. He instalocked it and then stayed in the the jg the whole time without ganking any lane. He claimed at the beginning he practiced with it but during the match said he was getting outplayed by the Kha'Zix on the other team. I said, "no you just suck" because he obviously wasnt a good jg and coupling that with the new champ made him even worse.

This is why people should be forced to play a certain amount of bot games before taking the champ into pvp.

Except you are playing against bots, which have no complex movements and don't leave lane for the first 20 minutes. The only way you can truly get good with a champ, outside of csing, is by playing real games. You should not be having this hard of time grasping that. 

Your example is even worse, because the jg in bot matches is completely unguarded and open for anything. There is no counterjungling and no rush to gank lanes because the bots are braindead.

Incorrect. The bots may not have dynamic and complex movements or anything like that, but it is the best way to understand new champs since you have no idea what the abilities will do and when the will do it.

By removing the human player aspect out of the opponent, you are free to understand the abilities and combos of your champ without worrying about if an enemy jg is going to gank you or if the opposing lane player is going to pull of a spell rotation that only a human player would do.

It gives you the freedom to practice with the champ to the point of familiarity and to where you feel comfortable enough to take it to PVP if you wish. That is what i do and i am very successful with it.

What you are suggesting is worse because then that makes it to where the champ constantly gets banned out or people in TB get overlooked due to the new champ and by that point, they get even LESS practice since no one wants them on their team. And that puts them even FURTHER back on practicing and getting used to the champ whereas if they were to go to bots, you wouldnt have that problem. The bots is mostly used for learning the champs abilities and spell combos to be comfortable enough to use them in PVP. I know there is no human aspect of actual PVP play, but that is not why you use bots. You use it for the reason i stated and that is to learn the champs abilities and combos.

You basically said that to get good with a champ, you need to play bots. I said that bots are good for learning to cs correctly and for understanding abilities, but that is it. In terms of jungling, the only time you will get legitimate experience is in actual games. Laning is SLIGHTLY different story, but in bot games, there is no rush to gank and no pressure in your own jungle. 

Regardless, if you play 100 games against bots with a champion, that does not mean anything when you translate that to an actual game against actual players.

Please show me where i said you have to play bots in order to get good at champs. I never said that nor did i ever imply that.

The point i was making was that people need to play bots to LEARN the champs to get comfortable enough to take it into PVP is they want to. No one in PVP wants to play with someone that is completely new to a champ nor do they want to play with someone who buys a new release champ and wants to try it out in ranked or regular PVP.

What you said was that the only way to get good at a champ outside of csing is by playing real games. Not to mention that you NEVER said ANYTHING about learning abilities. IM the one who said learning abilities. Im not in disagreement with playing real games to get good at a champ. But what i AM in disagreement with is the fact that people should automatically go into real games with first time champs that they have NO IDEA how to play them. That is why i said you need to play in bots for the first few games with a new champ just to get used to the abilities and THEN go into PVP.
